Subject: Question about hyperneat, NEVH and hidden layers
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=345796568; y=DCLnyAENIDHt9Lj40xJTRQ-MqDAAVIHkS_fkg8sAWfRi3cyu9s38jU7R

Although the papers on hyperneat propose some unique ways of
representing t=
he substrate geometrically, I got the impression that
the resulting generat=
ed net was always going to be 2 layer
feed-forward network (isn't the cppn =
used to construct this?). In the
paper on hyperneat checkers however, Jason=
 Gauci and Ken Stanley query
a single cppn to get connection weights for th=
e input/hidden layer,
and the hidden/output layer. (A Case Study on the Cri=
tical Role of
Geometric Regularity in Machine Learning)

Given that single =
layer feedforward networks were found incapable of
learning linearly insepe=
rable  patterns, it seems like the
functionality of NEVH could be severely =
hindered by limiting itself to
search the space of single-layer perceptrons=
. 

Is there a principled way of extending the method used by Gauci and
Sta=
nley in the checkers paper to making arbitrary amounts hidden
layers? Can a=
nyone provide any insights on whether limiting the
generated nets to single=
 layer actually inhibits their ability to
learn in the domain of humanoid b=
ipedal walking?
